00066 /**
00067  * \addtogroup VariableMath Variable Math
00068  * \brief Mathematic operations on and between variables.
00069  *
00070  * \description
00071  *
00072  *    This module provides three sets of functions for doing mathematic
00073  *    operations on and between variables. In general, these functions always
00074  *    create new variables which contain the desired result. There are
00075  *    versions for normal variables and analogous versions for sequence
00076  *    variables.
00077  *
00078  *    <b>1) Built-in operators</b>
00079  *
00080  *    The first group of functions, e.g. fc_operatorVar() and
00081  *    fc_varOperatorVar(), can be used to do built-in operations like '+' and
00082  *    '*'. Like built-in operations, they preserve or promote type as necessary
00083  *    with the major expectation that the resultants are only ever int
00084  *    or double. 
00085  *
00086  *    The FCLib function name indicates the type of variables to
00087  *    which the operator is applied (e.g., Var, SeqVar) and their order
00088  *    relative to the operator: i.e., fc_seqVarOperatorVar() can be used
00089  *    to take a seqvar and add a regular var to each of its values at
00090  *    each of its sequence steps. Thie mimics an operator's usage:
00091  *    arg1 op arg2. Currently all functions in this group
00092  *    that take a seqvar as at least of the arguments return a seqvar; all
00093  *    others return a var.
00094  *
00095  *    <b>2) User supplied functions</b>
00096  *
00097  *    The second group of functions, e.g. fc_varUnaryFunction() and
00098  *    fc_varBinaryFunctionVarVar(), allow the user to pass in a function that
00099  *    does the desired operation. The following example produces a new
00100  *    variables whose values are the square root of the values of the original
00101  *    variable ('sqrt' is a standard C math function):
00102  *
00103  *    \code 
00104  * fc_varUnaryFunction(var, sqrt, "sqrt", &newVar);
00105  *    \endcode
00106  *
00107  *    The FCLib function name indicates the type of variables
00108  *    (e.g., Var, SeqVar) to which the user's function is applied, their
00109  *     order as arguments to the function, and the return var type. 
00110  *    i.e., fc_seqVarBinaryFunctionSeqVarVar() can be used to take a 
00111  *    seqvar and, with a user supplied function to do an add, add a
00112  *    regular var to it each of its values at each of its
00113  *    sequence steps and the return value is a seqvar. This mimics
00114  *    a function's declaration: returntype functionname(arg1,arg2).
00115  *
00116  *
00117  *    <b>(1 & 2 Aside: Binary operations with a "constant")</b>
00118  *
00119  *    There are additional versions of the binary versions of these first type
00120  *    sets of functions that allow operations between a variable and a
00121  *    'constant'.  That is, a single (but can be multi-component) data point
00122  *    can be applied to all data points of the variable.  For example, the
00123  *    following scales a 3D vector by a factor of two:
00124  *    
00125  *    \code
00126  * int scale[3] = { 2, 2, 2 };
00127  * fc_varOperatorConst(vectorVar, '*', 3, scale, FC_DT_INT, "scaled vector", &newVar);
00128  *    \endcode
00129  *
00130  *    <b>3) Other</b>
00131  *
00132  *    The final set of functions provide operations that don't fit into
00133  *    the previous twos. Mostly these are functions that treat the different
00134  *    components of multicomponent variables differently. 
00135  *
00136  *
00137  * \modifications
00138  *    - 2003-JUN-23  W. Koegler  Created.
00139  *    - 02/02/04 RM, Redone, new implementation, added unary operators and 
00140  *                   general functions for unary and binary operations.
00141  *    - 02/23/04 RM, Added fc_varOperatorConst() 
00142  *    - 02/26/04 RM, Added user operator functions and examples for 
00143  *                   them, and functions for more advanced users 
00144  *    - 03/04/04 RM, Added examples of unary and binary user functions.
00145  *    - 11/10/04 WSK, reorg & rename. Also removed 'more sophisticated' unary &
00146  *                    binary functions as they were too general purpose.
00147  *                    (Might as well just write an entire new function.)
00148  *    - 6/03/05 ACG, adding analgous functions but for seqvar
00149  */
00150 
00151 /**
00152  * \ingroup  VariableMath
00153  * \defgroup  PrivateVariableMath (Private)
00154  *
00155  * \description
00156  *
00157  *    <b>Helper functions to perform built-in operations on data arrays.</b>
00158  *
00159  *       - _fc_negateInts()
00160  *       - _fc_negateDoubles()
00161  *       - _fc_addInts()
00162  *       - _fc_subtractInts()
00163  *       - _fc_multiplyInts()
00164  *       - _fc_divideInts()
00165  *       - _fc_addDoubles()
00166  *       - _fc_subtractDoubles()
00167  *       - _fc_multiplyDoubles()
00168  *       - _fc_divideDoubles()
00169  *   
00170  *    The motivation for using these functions (as opposed to using
00171  *    fc_varUnaryFunction() and similar functions) are: 1) it is more
00172  *    efficient to do built-in operation over entire array than to embed the
00173  *    operation in a function that is called repeatedly; and 2) we are also
00174  *    using them help to retain type when appropriate (i.e. if you add two
00175  *    ints, you get an int).
00176  *
00177  *    All of the built-in helper functions assume that the calling program has
00178  *    allocated room for the results.
00179  *
00180  *    The binary built-in helper functions operate on interleaved data
00181  *    arrays--that is if you have numData data points and numComp components,
00182  *    the jth component of the ith data point is found by data[i*numComp+j].
00183  *    All data arrays are assume to have the same number of components.  If
00184  *    they also have the same number of data points, the operation is performed
00185  *    for each data value. A special case is allowed for when one of the data
00186  *    arrays has just one data point.  In that case, that single data point is
00187  *    used for all data points of the other array.
00188  */
00189 
00190 /** \name Built in operators on variables. */
00191 //-------------------------------
00192 //@{
00193 
00194 /**
00195  * \ingroup  VariableMath
00196  * \brief Performs built-in unary operations on a variable.
00197  *
00198  * \description
00199  *
00200  *    Given a string that represents the desired unary operation, return
00201  *    a new variable with the result of that operation performed on the
00202  *    given variable.
00203  *
00204  *    Supported operations are:
00205  *      - <tt> "-"  =>  -var </tt>
00206  *
00207  *    The new variable will be on the same mesh as the original and will
00208  *    have the same association and math type as the original. The operation
00209  *    is performed on each component of each data point. 
00210  *  
00211  *    If the original variable had data type FC_DT_INT, then the result
00212  *    will have data type FC_DT_INT. If the original variable had data type
00213  *    FC_DT_FLOAT or FC_DT_DOUBLE, the result will have data type FC_DT_DOUBLE.
00214  *    The function returns with an error if the data type is FC_DT_CHAR.
00215  *
00216  * \modifications 
00217  *    - 02/02/04  R.McCoy  Created.
00218  *    - 11/09/03  WSK, restricted to built-in types.
00219  */
00220 FC_ReturnCode fc_operatorVar(
00221   FC_Variable var,      /**< input - variable */
00222   char* operation,      /**< input - operation to be performed on variable */
00223   char* new_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */
00224   FC_Variable* new_var  /**< output - the new variable */
00225 ) {
00226   FC_ReturnCode rc;
00227   int i;
00228   int opID;
00229   int numData, numComp;
00230   FC_AssociationType assoc, new_datatype;
00231   FC_DataType datatype;
00232   FC_MathType mathtype;
00233   void *data, *resultPtr;
00234   double *dblDataPtr;
00235   // create array of pointers to int & double array functions
00236   FC_ReturnCode (*IntUnaryOper[])(int, int*, int*) = { 
00237                          _fc_negateInts
00238                         };
00239   FC_ReturnCode (*DblUnaryOper[])(int, double*, double*) = {
00240                           _fc_negateDoubles 
00241                         }; 
00242 
00243   // set default return value
00244   if (new_var)
00245     *new_var = FC_NULL_VARIABLE;
00246   
00247   // check input
00248   if (!(fc_isVariableValid(var)) || !operation || !new_var || !new_var_name) {
00249     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
00250     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00251   }
00252 
00253   // pick operation
00254   if (!strcmp(operation, "-")) 
00255     opID = 0;
00256   else {
00257     fc_printfErrorMessage("operation '%s' not recognized.", operation); 
00258     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00259   }
00260   
00261   // log message
00262   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing unary operation '%s' on variable '%s'",
00263             operation, _fc_getVarSlot(var)->header.name);
00264 
00265   // get variable info
00266   rc = fc_getVariableInfo(var, &numData, &numComp, &assoc, 
00267                  &mathtype, &datatype);
00268   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00269     return rc;
00270 
00271   // check that the datatype can be handled here
00272   if (datatype != FC_DT_INT && datatype != FC_DT_FLOAT && 
00273       datatype != FC_DT_DOUBLE) {
00274     fc_printfErrorMessage("data type '%s' cannot be handled.", 
00275                  fc_getDataTypeText(datatype));
00276     return FC_ERROR;
00277   } 
00278 
00279   // get data
00280   rc = fc_getVariableDataPtr(var, &data);
00281   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00282     return rc;
00283 
00284   if (datatype == FC_DT_INT) {
00285     new_datatype = FC_DT_INT;
00286     resultPtr = (int*)malloc(sizeof(int)*numComp*numData);
00287     if (resultPtr == NULL) {
00288       fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));  
00289       return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
00290     }
00291     rc = (*IntUnaryOper[opID])(numComp*numData, (int*)data, (int*)resultPtr);
00292     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00293       return rc;
00294   }
00295   else {
00296     new_datatype = FC_DT_DOUBLE;
00297 
00298      // get double representation of data
00299     if (datatype == FC_DT_DOUBLE)
00300       dblDataPtr = (double*)data;
00301     else if (datatype == FC_DT_FLOAT) {
00302       float* cast_data = (float*)data;
00303       dblDataPtr = malloc(sizeof(double)*numComp*numData);
00304       if (dblDataPtr == NULL) {
00305      fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));  
00306      return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
00307       }
00308       for (i = 0; i < numComp*numData; i++)
00309      dblDataPtr[i] = cast_data[i];
00310     }
00311 
00312     // do it
00313     resultPtr = malloc(sizeof(double)*numComp*numData);
00314     if (resultPtr == NULL) {
00315       fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));  
00316       return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
00317     }
00318     rc = (*DblUnaryOper[opID])(numComp*numData, (double*)dblDataPtr, 
00319                       (double*)resultPtr);
00320     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00321       return rc;
00322     
00323     // deallocate memory if it was allocated
00324     if (datatype != FC_DT_DOUBLE)
00325       free(dblDataPtr);
00326   }
00327  
00328   // create the new variable
00329   if (fc_isVariableGlobal(var)) {
00330     FC_Dataset dataset;
00331     rc = fc_getDatasetFromVariable(var, &dataset);
00332     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00333       return rc;
00334     rc = fc_createGlobalVariable(dataset, new_var_name, new_var);
00335     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00336       return rc; 
00337   }
00338   else {
00339     FC_Mesh mesh;
00340     rc = fc_getMeshFromVariable(var, &mesh);
00341     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00342       return rc;
00343     rc = fc_createVariable(mesh, new_var_name, new_var);
00344     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00345       return rc; 
00346   }
00347   rc = fc_setVariableDataPtr(*new_var, numData, numComp, assoc, mathtype, 
00348                     new_datatype, resultPtr);
00349   return rc;    
00350 
00351 } 
00352 
00353 /**
00354  * \ingroup  VariableMath
00355  * \brief Performs built-in binary operation on two variables.
00356  *
00357  * \description 
00358  *
00359  *   Given a string that represents the desired binary operation, return a new
00360  *   variable with the result of that operation performed on the the given
00361  *   variables.
00362  *
00363  *    Supported operations are:
00364  *     - <tt> "+"  =>  var1 + var2 </tt>
00365  *     - <tt> "-"  =>  var1 - var2 </tt>
00366  *     - <tt> "*"  =>  var1 * var2 </tt>
00367  *     - <tt> "/"  =>  var1 / var2 </tt>
00368  * 
00369  *    The two variables must have the same number of data points and the same
00370  *    number of components.
00371  *
00372  *    The new variable will be on the same mesh and have the same association
00373  *    and mathtype as the first variable. The operation is performed per
00374  *    component and data point.
00375  *
00376  *    If both original variables have the data type FC_DT_INT, then the 
00377  *    operation will be an integer operation and the result
00378  *    will have data type FC_DT_INT. Otherwise, all variable values are
00379  *    promoted to double and the operation will be a double operation and
00380  *    the result will have data type FC_DT_DOUBLE.
00381  *
00382  * \modifications 
00383  *    - 01/29/04  R.McCoy  Created.
00384  *    - 11/09/03  WSK, restricted to built-in types.
00385  */
00386 FC_ReturnCode fc_varOperatorVar(
00387   FC_Variable var1,     /**< input - variable 1  */
00388   char* operation,      /**< input - operation to be performed on variables */
00389   FC_Variable var2,     /**< input - variable 2  */
00390   char* new_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */
00391   FC_Variable* new_var  /**< output - the new variable */
00392 ) {        
00393   FC_ReturnCode rc;
00394   int numData1, numData2, numComp1, numComp2;
00395   FC_DataType datatype1, datatype2;
00396   void *data1, *data2;
00397    
00398   // set default return value
00399   if (new_var)
00400     *new_var = FC_NULL_VARIABLE;
00401 
00402   // check input
00403   if (!(fc_isVariableValid(var1)) || !operation || 
00404       !(fc_isVariableValid(var2)) || !new_var_name || !new_var) {
00405     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));   
00406     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00407   }
00408  
00409   // log message
00410   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing operation (var1 %s var2), with var1 = '%s', "
00411            "var2 = '%s'" , operation, _fc_getVarSlot(var1)->header.name,
00412            _fc_getVarSlot(var2)->header.name);  
00413 
00414   // get variable info
00415   rc = fc_getVariableInfo(var1, &numData1, &numComp1, NULL, NULL, &datatype1);
00416   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00417     return rc;
00418   rc = fc_getVariableInfo(var2, &numData2, &numComp2, NULL, NULL, &datatype2);
00419   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00420     return rc;
00421 
00422   // check that variables are similar enough
00423   if (numData1 != numData2 || numComp1 != numComp2) {
00424     fc_printfErrorMessage("Vars need to have same number of data points "
00425                  "and same number of components");
00426     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00427   }
00428   if ((fc_isVariableGlobal(var1) && !fc_isVariableGlobal(var2)) ||
00429       (!fc_isVariableGlobal(var1) && fc_isVariableGlobal(var2))) {
00430     fc_printfErrorMessage("Cannot process a mix of global and non-global vars");
00431     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00432   }
00433 
00434   // get data
00435   rc = fc_getVariableDataPtr(var1, &data1);
00436   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00437     return rc;
00438   rc = fc_getVariableDataPtr(var2, &data2);
00439   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00440     return rc;
00441 
00442   // do it
00443   return _fc_binaryOperatorCore(numComp1, numData1, data1, datatype1,
00444                     operation, numData2, data2, datatype2,
00445                     var1, new_var_name, new_var);
00446 }
00447 
00448 /**
00449  * \ingroup  VariableMath
00450  * \brief Performs built-in binary operation on a variable and a constant. 
00451  *
00452  * \description  
00453  *
00454  *   Given a string that represents the desired binary operation, return a new
00455  *   variable with the result of that operation performed with the constant
00456  *   on each data point of the variable. Use fc_constOperatorVar() to apply
00457  *   operation in reverse order.
00458  *
00459  *    Supported operations are:
00460  *     - <tt> "+"  =>  var + const </tt>
00461  *     - <tt> "-"  =>  var - const </tt>
00462  *     - <tt> "*"  =>  var * const </tt>
00463  *     - <tt> "/"  =>  var / const </tt>
00464  * 
00465  *    The variables and the constant must have the same number of components.
00466  *
00467  *    The new variable will be on the same mesh and have the same association
00468  *    and mathtype as the variable. The operation is performed per component
00469  *    and data point.
00470  *
00471  *    If both the variable and the constant have the data type FC_DT_INT, then
00472  *    the operation will be an integer operation and the result will have data
00473  *    type FC_DT_INT. Otherwise, all values are promoted to double and the
00474  *    operation will be a double operation and the result will have data type
00475  *    FC_DT_DOUBLE.
00476  *
00477  * \modifications 
00478  *    - 02/19/04  R.McCoy  Created.
00479  *    - 11/09/03  WSK, restricted to built-in types.
00480  */
00481 FC_ReturnCode fc_varOperatorConst(
00482   FC_Variable var,       /**< input - FCLib variable */
00483   char* operation,       /**< input - operation to be performed on variables */
00484   int constNumComp,      /**< input - number of components in constVector */
00485   void* constVector,     /**< input - constant vector  */
00486   FC_DataType constType, /**< input - data type of constVector*/
00487   char* new_var_name,    /**< input - name for the new variable */
00488   FC_Variable* new_var   /**< output - the new variable */
00489 ) {
00490   FC_ReturnCode rc;
00491   int numComp, numData;
00492   FC_DataType datatype; 
00493   void *data; 
00494    
00495   // set default return value
00496   if (new_var)
00497     *new_var = FC_NULL_VARIABLE;
00498     
00499   // check input
00500   if (!(fc_isVariableValid(var)) || !operation || constNumComp < 1 ||
00501       !constVector || !fc_isDataTypeValid(constType) || 
00502       constType == FC_DT_UNKNOWN || !new_var_name  || !new_var) {
00503     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));   
00504     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00505   }
00506 
00507   // log message
00508   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing operation (var %s const), with var '%s'",
00509                 operation, _fc_getVarSlot(var)->header.name);
00510 
00511   // get variable info
00512   rc = fc_getVariableInfo(var, &numData, &numComp, NULL, NULL, &datatype);
00513   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00514     return rc;
00515 
00516   // check that const is similar enough
00517   if (numComp != constNumComp) {
00518     fc_printfErrorMessage("constant need sot have same number of components "
00519                  "as var");
00520     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00521   }
00522 
00523   // get data
00524   rc = fc_getVariableDataPtr(var, &data);
00525   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00526     return rc;
00527 
00528   // do it
00529   return _fc_binaryOperatorCore(numComp, numData, data, datatype,
00530                     operation, 1, constVector, constType,
00531                     var, new_var_name, new_var);
00532 }
00533 
00534 /**
00535  * \ingroup  VariableMath
00536  * \brief Performs built-in binary operation on a constant and a variable. 
00537  *
00538  * \description
00539  * 
00540  *   Given a string that represents the desired binary operation, return a new
00541  *   variable with the result of that operation performed with the constant
00542  *   on each data point of the variable. Use fc_varOperatorConst() to apply
00543  *   operation in reverse order.
00544  *
00545  *    Supported operations are:
00546  *     - <tt> "+"  =>  const + var </tt>
00547  *     - <tt> "-"  =>  const - var </tt>
00548  *     - <tt> "*"  =>  const * var </tt>
00549  *     - <tt> "/"  =>  const / var </tt>
00550  * 
00551  *    The variables and the constant must have the same number of components.
00552  *
00553  *    The new variable will be on the same mesh and have the same association
00554  *    and mathtype as the variable. The operation is performed per component
00555  *    and data point.
00556  *
00557  *    If both the variable and the constant have the data type FC_DT_INT, then
00558  *    the operation will be an integer operation and the result will have data
00559  *    type FC_DT_INT. Otherwise, all values are promoted to double and the
00560  *    operation will be a double operation and the result will have data type
00561  *    FC_DT_DOUBLE.
00562  *
00563  * \modifications 
00564  *    - 11/09/03  WSK, created to complement fc_varOperatorConst.
00565  */
00566 FC_ReturnCode fc_constOperatorVar(
00567   int constNumComp,      /**< input - number of components in constVector */
00568   void* constVector,     /**< input - constant vector  */
00569   FC_DataType constType, /**< input - data type of constVector*/
00570   char* operation,       /**< input - operation to be performed on variables */
00571   FC_Variable var,       /**< input - FCLib variable */
00572   char* new_var_name,    /**< input - name for the new variable */
00573   FC_Variable* new_var   /**< output - the new variable */
00574 ) {
00575   FC_ReturnCode rc;
00576   int numComp, numData;
00577   FC_DataType datatype;
00578   void *data; 
00579    
00580   // set default return value
00581   if (new_var)
00582     *new_var = FC_NULL_VARIABLE;
00583     
00584   // check input
00585   if (!(fc_isVariableValid(var)) || !operation || constNumComp < 1 ||
00586       !constVector || !fc_isDataTypeValid(constType) || 
00587       constType == FC_DT_UNKNOWN || !new_var_name  || !new_var) {
00588     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));   
00589     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00590   }
00591 
00592   // log message
00593   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing operation (var %s const), with var '%s'",
00594                 operation, _fc_getVarSlot(var)->header.name);
00595 
00596   // get variable info
00597   rc = fc_getVariableInfo(var, &numData, &numComp, NULL, NULL, &datatype);
00598   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00599     return rc;
00600 
00601   // check that const is similar enough
00602   if (numComp != constNumComp) {
00603     fc_printfErrorMessage("constant need sot have same number of components "
00604                  "as var");
00605     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00606   }
00607 
00608   // get data
00609   rc = fc_getVariableDataPtr(var, &data);
00610   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00611     return rc;
00612  
00613   return _fc_binaryOperatorCore(numComp, 1, constVector, constType, operation,
00614                     numData, data, datatype,
00615                     var, new_var_name, new_var);
00616 }
00617 
00618 //@}
00619 
00620 /** \name Built-in operators on sequence variables. */
00621 //-------------------------------
00622 //@{
00623 
00624 /**
00625  * \ingroup  VariableMath
00626  * \brief Performs built-in unary operations on a sequence variable.
00627  *
00628  * \description
00629  *
00630  *    Given a string that represents the desired unary operation, return
00631  *    a new sequence variable with the result of that operation
00632  *    performed on each step of the given sequence variable. This is the
00633  *    sequence variable analogy to fc_operatorVar();
00634  *
00635  *    Supported operations are:
00636  *      - <tt> "-"  =>  -var </tt>
00637  *
00638  *    The new sequence variable will be on the same mesh and sequence as the 
00639  *    original and will have the same association and math type as
00640  *    the original. The operation is performed on each component of each 
00641  *    data point at each sequence step. 
00642  *  
00643  *    If the original sequence variable had data type FC_DT_INT, 
00644  *    then the result
00645  *    will have data type FC_DT_INT. If the original sequence variable had
00646  *    data type FC_DT_FLOAT or FC_DT_DOUBLE, the result will have data
00647  *    type FC_DT_DOUBLE. The function returns with an error if the data
00648  *    type is FC_DT_CHAR.
00649  *
00650  * \modifications 
00651  *    - 06/03/04  ACG  Created.
00652  *    - 06/07/05  ACG removing datatype check and leaving that to internal call
00653  *    - 01/24/06  WSK Rewrote innards to mimimize data creation.
00654  */
00655 FC_ReturnCode fc_operatorSeqVar(
00656   int numStep,      /**< input - numstep in the input seq var */           
00657   FC_Variable *seq_var,      /**< input - seq variable */
00658   char* operation,      /**< input - operation to be performed on variable */
00659   char* new_seq_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new seq variable */
00660   FC_Variable** new_seq_var  /**< output - the new seq variable */
00661 ) {
00662   FC_ReturnCode rc;
00663   FC_Sequence seq;
00664   FC_Variable* temp_vars;
00665   int i, j;
00666 
00667   // default return
00668   if (new_seq_var)
00669     *new_seq_var = NULL;
00670 
00671   // check input
00672   if ((!fc_isSeqVariableValid(numStep,seq_var)) || (new_seq_var == NULL)
00673       || new_seq_var_name == NULL){
00674     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
00675     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00676   }
00677   //other checks are done internally in operatorvar
00678 
00679   // log message
00680   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing operatorSeqVar '%s' on variable '%s'",
00681             operation, _fc_getVarSlot(seq_var[0])->header.name);
00682 
00683   // Get info
00684   rc = fc_getSequenceFromSeqVariable(numStep,seq_var,&seq);
00685   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00686     return rc;
00687 
00688   // Make space to save temp_vars
00689   temp_vars = malloc(numStep*sizeof(FC_Variable));
00690   if (!temp_vars) {
00691     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
00692     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
00693   }
00694   
00695   // Do calculation on each step of the seq variables
00696   for (i = 0; i < numStep; i++) {
00697     rc = fc_operatorVar(seq_var[i], operation, "junk_var", &temp_vars[i]);
00698     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS) {
00699       for (j = 0; j < i-1; j++)
00700      fc_deleteVariable(temp_vars[j]);
00701       fc_printfErrorMessage("Operation failed on step %d", i);
00702       free(temp_vars);
00703       return rc;
00704     }
00705   }
00706 
00707   // stitch steps into the new seq var
00708   rc = fc_convertVariablesToSeqVariable(numStep, temp_vars, seq,
00709                          new_seq_var_name, new_seq_var);
00710   free(temp_vars);
00711   return rc;
00712 }
00713 
00714 /**
00715  * \ingroup  VariableMath
00716  * \brief Performs built-in binary operation on two seq variables.
00717  *
00718  * \description 
00719  *
00720  *   Given a string that represents the desired binary operation, return a new
00721  *   seq variable with the result of that operation performed on the the given
00722  *   seq variables. This is the seq var version of fc_varOperatorVar.
00723  *
00724  *    Supported operations are:
00725  *     - <tt> "+"  =>  var1 + var2 </tt>
00726  *     - <tt> "-"  =>  var1 - var2 </tt>
00727  *     - <tt> "*"  =>  var1 * var2 </tt>
00728  *     - <tt> "/"  =>  var1 / var2 </tt>
00729  * 
00730  *    The two seq variables must have the same number of data points and the same
00731  *    number of components and be on the same sequence.
00732  *
00733  *    The seq new variable will be on the same mesh and have the same association
00734  *    and mathtype as the first variable. The operation is performed per
00735  *    component and data point at each sequence step.
00736  *
00737  *    If both original variables have the data type FC_DT_INT, then the 
00738  *    operation will be an integer operation and the result
00739  *    will have data type FC_DT_INT. Otherwise, all variable values are
00740  *    promoted to double and the operation will be a double operation and
00741  *    the result will have data type FC_DT_DOUBLE.
00742  *
00743  * \modifications 
00744  *    - 06/07/05  ACG  Created.
00745  *    - 01/24/06  WSK Rewrote innards to mimimize data creation.
00746  */
00747 FC_ReturnCode fc_seqVarOperatorSeqVar(
00748   int numStep, /**< input - num step in input seq var */
00749   FC_Variable *seq_var1, /**< input seq var1 */
00750   char* operation,      /**< input - operation to be performed on variables */
00751   FC_Variable *seq_var2, /**< input seq var2 */
00752   char* new_seq_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */ 
00753   FC_Variable** new_seq_var  /**< output - the new seq variable */
00754 ) {   
00755   FC_ReturnCode rc;
00756   FC_Sequence seq1, seq2;
00757   FC_Variable* temp_vars;
00758   int i, j;
00759 
00760   // default return
00761   if (new_seq_var)
00762     *new_seq_var = NULL;
00763 
00764   // check input (this indirectly checks that numStep is the same on both seqs
00765   if ((!fc_isSeqVariableValid(numStep,seq_var1)) ||
00766       (!fc_isSeqVariableValid(numStep,seq_var2)) ||
00767       (new_seq_var == NULL) || new_seq_var_name == NULL){
00768     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
00769     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00770   }
00771   //other checks are done internally in varoperatorvar
00772 
00773   // log message
00774   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing SeqVarOperatorSeqVar '%s' on"
00775                 "seq variables '%s' and '%s'", operation,
00776                 _fc_getVarSlot(seq_var1[0])->header.name,
00777                 _fc_getVarSlot(seq_var2[0])->header.name);
00778 
00779   // get info
00780   rc = fc_getSequenceFromSeqVariable(numStep,seq_var1,&seq1);
00781   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00782     return rc;
00783   rc = fc_getSequenceFromSeqVariable(numStep,seq_var2,&seq2);
00784   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00785     return rc;
00786   // FIX? remove this?
00787   if (!(FC_HANDLE_EQUIV(seq1,seq2))){
00788     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", "Variables are not on the same sequence");
00789     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00790   }
00791 
00792   // Make space to save temp_vars
00793   temp_vars = malloc(numStep*sizeof(FC_Variable));
00794   if (!temp_vars) {
00795     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
00796     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
00797   }
00798 
00799   // Do calculation on each step of the seq variables
00800   for (i = 0; i < numStep; i++) {
00801     rc = fc_varOperatorVar(seq_var1[i], operation, seq_var2[i], "junk_var",
00802                   &temp_vars[i]); 
00803     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS) { 
00804       for (j = 0; j < i-1; j++)
00805      fc_deleteVariable(temp_vars[j]);
00806       free(temp_vars);
00807       fc_printfErrorMessage("Operation failed on step %d", i);
00808       return rc;
00809     }
00810   }
00811 
00812   // stitch steps into the new seq var
00813   rc = fc_convertVariablesToSeqVariable(numStep, temp_vars, seq1,
00814                          new_seq_var_name, new_seq_var);
00815   free(temp_vars);
00816   return rc;
00817 }
00818 
00819 /**
00820  * \ingroup  VariableMath
00821  * \brief Performs built-in binary operation on a seq variable a seq of constants.
00822  *
00823  * \description 
00824  *
00825  *   Given a string that represents the desired binary operation, return a new
00826  *   seq variable with the result of that operation performed on the the given
00827  *   seq of constants. Use \ref fc_seqConstOperatorSeqVar() to apply the
00828  *   operation in the reverse order.
00829  *
00830  *   This is the seq var version of \ref fc_varOperatorConst() where a
00831  *   different constant vector is applied to each step of the sequence
00832  *   variable. The constant values should be an array with all components for
00833  *   the first step first, then all components for the next step, etc.
00834  *   If you would like to apply the same constant to all steps, use
00835  *   fc_seqVarOperatorConst(). 
00836  *
00837  *    Supported operations are:
00838  *     - <tt> "+"  =>  var + const </tt>
00839  *     - <tt> "-"  =>  var - const </tt>
00840  *     - <tt> "*"  =>  var * const </tt>
00841  *     - <tt> "/"  =>  var / const </tt>
00842  * 
00843  *    The seq variable and the constants must have the same number components.
00844  *
00845  *    The seq new variable will be on the same mesh and have the same association
00846  *    and mathtype as the seq variable. The operation is performed per
00847  *    component and data point at each sequence step.
00848  *
00849  *    If both the original variable and the constants have the data type
00850  *    FC_DT_INT, then the operation will be an integer operation and the result
00851  *    will have data type FC_DT_INT. Otherwise, all variable values are
00852  *    promoted to double and the operation will be a double operation and the
00853  *    result will have data type FC_DT_DOUBLE.
00854  *
00855  * \modifications 
00856  *    - 11/20/2006 WSD Created.
00857  */
00858 FC_ReturnCode fc_seqVarOperatorSeqConst(
00859   int numStep,           /**< input - num step in input seq var and const */
00860   FC_Variable *seq_var1, /**< input seq var1 */
00861   char* operation,       /**< input - operation to be performed on variables */
00862   int constNumComp,      /**< input - number of components in constVector */
00863   void* constVectors,    /**< input - constant vectors, stored as vector for
00864                           first step, then vector for next step, etc. */
00865   FC_DataType constType, /**< input - data type of constVector */
00866   char* new_seq_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */ 
00867   FC_Variable** new_seq_var  /**< output - the new seq variable */
00868 ) {   
00869   FC_ReturnCode rc;
00870   FC_Sequence seq;
00871   FC_Variable* temp_vars;
00872   int i, j;
00873 
00874   // default return
00875   if (new_seq_var)
00876     *new_seq_var = NULL;
00877 
00878   // check input (this indirectly checks that numStep is the same on both seqs
00879   if (!fc_isSeqVariableValid(numStep, seq_var1) || !operation || 
00880       constNumComp < 1 || !constVectors || !fc_isDataTypeValid(constType) ||
00881       constType == FC_DT_UNKNOWN || new_seq_var_name == NULL ||
00882       new_seq_var == NULL) {
00883     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
00884     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00885   }
00886   //other checks are done internally in varoperatorconst
00887 
00888   // log message
00889   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing SeqVarOperatorSeqConst '%s' with"
00890                 "seq variable '%s'", operation,
00891                 _fc_getVarSlot(seq_var1[0])->header.name);
00892 
00893   // get info
00894   rc = fc_getSequenceFromSeqVariable(numStep, seq_var1, &seq);
00895   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
00896     return rc;
00897 
00898   // Make space to save temp_vars
00899   temp_vars = malloc(numStep*sizeof(FC_Variable));
00900   if (!temp_vars) {
00901     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
00902     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
00903   }
00904 
00905   // Do calculation on each step of the seq variables
00906   for (i = 0; i < numStep; i++) {
00907     void* temp_constVector;
00908     switch(constType) {
00909     case FC_DT_CHAR:
00910       temp_constVector = &((char*)constVectors)[i*constNumComp]; break;
00911     case  FC_DT_INT: 
00912       temp_constVector = &((int*)constVectors)[i*constNumComp]; break;
00913     case FC_DT_FLOAT:
00914       temp_constVector = &((float*)constVectors)[i*constNumComp]; break;
00915     case FC_DT_DOUBLE:
00916       temp_constVector = &((double*)constVectors)[i*constNumComp]; break;
00917     case FC_DT_UNKNOWN:
00918       fc_printfErrorMessage("should never get here");
00919       return FC_ERROR;
00920     }
00921     rc = fc_varOperatorConst(seq_var1[i], operation, constNumComp, 
00922                             temp_constVector, constType,
00923                              "junk_var", &temp_vars[i]); 
00924     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS) { 
00925       for (j = 0; j < i-1; j++)
00926      fc_deleteVariable(temp_vars[j]);
00927       free(temp_vars);
00928       fc_printfErrorMessage("Operation failed on step %d", i);
00929       return rc;
00930     }
00931   }
00932 
00933   // stitch steps into the new seq var
00934   rc = fc_convertVariablesToSeqVariable(numStep, temp_vars, seq,
00935                          new_seq_var_name, new_seq_var);
00936   free(temp_vars);
00937   return rc;
00938 }
00939 
00940 /**
00941  * \ingroup  VariableMath
00942  * \brief Performs built-in binary operation on a seq variable a seq of constants.
00943  *
00944  * \description 
00945  *
00946  *   Given a string that represents the desired binary operation, return a new
00947  *   seq variable with the result of that operation performed on the the given
00948  *   seq of constants. Use \ref fc_seqVarOperatorSeqConst() to apply the
00949  *   operation in the reverse order.
00950  *
00951  *   This is the seq var version of \ref fc_constOperatorVar() where a
00952  *   different constant vector is applied to each step of the sequence
00953  *   variable. The constant values should be an array with all components for
00954  *   the first step first, then all components for the next step, etc.
00955  *   If you would like to apply the same constant to all steps, use
00956  *   fc_constOperatorSeqVar(). 
00957  *
00958  *    Supported operations are:
00959  *     - <tt> "+"  =>  const + var </tt>
00960  *     - <tt> "-"  =>  const - var </tt>
00961  *     - <tt> "*"  =>  const * var </tt>
00962  *     - <tt> "/"  =>  const / var </tt>
00963  * 
00964  *    The seq variable and the constants must have the same number components.
00965  *
00966  *    The seq new variable will be on the same mesh and have the same association
00967  *    and mathtype as the seq variable. The operation is performed per
00968  *    component and data point at each sequence step.
00969  *
00970  *    If both the original variable and the constants have the data type
00971  *    FC_DT_INT, then the operation will be an integer operation and the result
00972  *    will have data type FC_DT_INT. Otherwise, all variable values are
00973  *    promoted to double and the operation will be a double operation and the
00974  *    result will have data type FC_DT_DOUBLE.
00975  *
00976  * \modifications 
00977  *    - 11/20/2006 WSD Created.
00978  */
00979 FC_ReturnCode fc_seqConstOperatorSeqVar(
00980   int numStep,           /**< input - num step in input seq var and const */
00981   int constNumComp,      /**< input - number of components in constVector */
00982   void* constVectors,    /**< input - constant vectors, stored as vector for
00983                           first step, then vector for next step, etc. */
00984   FC_DataType constType, /**< input - data type of constVector */
00985   char* operation,       /**< input - operation to be performed on variables */
00986   FC_Variable *seq_var2, /**< input seq var2 */
00987   char* new_seq_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */ 
00988   FC_Variable** new_seq_var  /**< output - the new seq variable */
00989 ) {   
00990   FC_ReturnCode rc;
00991   FC_Sequence seq;
00992   FC_Variable* temp_vars;
00993   int i, j;
00994 
00995   // default return
00996   if (new_seq_var)
00997     *new_seq_var = NULL;
00998 
00999   // check input (this indirectly checks that numStep is the same on both seqs
01000   if (!fc_isSeqVariableValid(numStep, seq_var2) || !operation || 
01001       constNumComp < 1 || !constVectors || !fc_isDataTypeValid(constType) ||
01002       constType == FC_DT_UNKNOWN || new_seq_var_name == NULL ||
01003       new_seq_var == NULL) {
01004     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
01005     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01006   }
01007   //other checks are done internally in varoperatorconst
01008 
01009   // log message
01010   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing SeqVarOperatorSeqConst '%s' with"
01011                 "seq variable '%s'", operation,
01012                 _fc_getVarSlot(seq_var2[0])->header.name);
01013 
01014   // get info
01015   rc = fc_getSequenceFromSeqVariable(numStep, seq_var2, &seq);
01016   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01017     return rc;
01018 
01019   // Make space to save temp_vars
01020   temp_vars = malloc(numStep*sizeof(FC_Variable));
01021   if (!temp_vars) {
01022     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
01023     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
01024   }
01025 
01026   // Do calculation on each step of the seq variables
01027   for (i = 0; i < numStep; i++) {
01028     void* temp_constVector;
01029     switch(constType) {
01030     case FC_DT_CHAR:
01031       temp_constVector = &((char*)constVectors)[i*constNumComp]; break;
01032     case  FC_DT_INT: 
01033       temp_constVector = &((int*)constVectors)[i*constNumComp]; break;
01034     case FC_DT_FLOAT:
01035       temp_constVector = &((float*)constVectors)[i*constNumComp]; break;
01036     case FC_DT_DOUBLE:
01037       temp_constVector = &((double*)constVectors)[i*constNumComp]; break;
01038     case FC_DT_UNKNOWN:
01039       fc_printfErrorMessage("should never get here");
01040       return FC_ERROR;
01041     }
01042     rc = fc_constOperatorVar(constNumComp, temp_constVector, constType,
01043                              operation, seq_var2[i], 
01044                              "junk_var", &temp_vars[i]); 
01045     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS) { 
01046       for (j = 0; j < i-1; j++)
01047      fc_deleteVariable(temp_vars[j]);
01048       free(temp_vars);
01049       fc_printfErrorMessage("Operation failed on step %d", i);
01050       return rc;
01051     }
01052   }
01053 
01054   // stitch steps into the new seq var
01055   rc = fc_convertVariablesToSeqVariable(numStep, temp_vars, seq,
01056                          new_seq_var_name, new_seq_var);
01057   free(temp_vars);
01058   return rc;
01059 }
01060 
01061 /** \name Built-in operators between variables and sequence variables. */
01062 //-------------------------------
01063 //@{
01064 
01065 /**
01066  * \ingroup  VariableMath
01067  * \brief Performs built-in binary operation on a seq variable and a normal var.
01068  *
01069  * \description 
01070  *
01071  *   Given a string that represents the desired binary operation, return a new
01072  *   seq variable with the result of that operation between a given
01073  *   seq variable and a normal var applied at each sequence step.
01074  *   For example, one can use this to scale a seqvar's values by their mean over
01075  *   the sequence (e.g., time).
01076  *
01077  *    Supported operations are:
01078  *     - <tt> "+"  =>  var1 + var2 </tt>
01079  *     - <tt> "-"  =>  var1 - var2 </tt>
01080  *     - <tt> "*"  =>  var1 * var2 </tt>
01081  *     - <tt> "/"  =>  var1 / var2 </tt>
01082  * 
01083  *    The two seq variable and the normal variable must have the same number of data
01084  *    points and the same number of components.
01085  *
01086  *    The seq new variable will be on the same mesh and sequence and will have the
01087  *    same association and mathtype as the seq variable. The operation is 
01088  *    performed per component and data point at each sequence step.
01089  *
01090  *    If both original variables have the data type FC_DT_INT, then the 
01091  *    operation will be an integer operation and the result
01092  *    will have data type FC_DT_INT. Otherwise, all variable values are
01093  *    promoted to double and the operation will be a double operation and
01094  *    the result will have data type FC_DT_DOUBLE.
01095  *    - 01/24/06  WSK Rewrote innards to mimimize data creation.
01096  *
01097  * \modifications 
01098  *    - 06/07/05  ACG  Created.
01099  *    - 01/24/06  WSK Rewrote innards to mimimize data creation.
01100  */
01101 FC_ReturnCode fc_seqVarOperatorVar(
01102   int numStep, /**< input - num step in input seq var */
01103   FC_Variable *seq_var1, /**< input seq var1 */
01104   char* operation,      /**< input - operation to be performed on variables */
01105   FC_Variable var2, /**< input var */
01106   char* new_seq_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */ 
01107   FC_Variable** new_seq_var  /**< output - the new seq variable */
01108 ) {   
01109   FC_ReturnCode rc;
01110   FC_Sequence seq;
01111   FC_Variable* temp_vars;
01112   int i, j;
01113 
01114   // default return
01115   if (new_seq_var)
01116     *new_seq_var = NULL;
01117 
01118   // check input
01119   if ((!fc_isSeqVariableValid(numStep, seq_var1)) ||
01120       (!fc_isVariableValid(var2)) ||
01121       (new_seq_var == NULL) || new_seq_var_name == NULL){
01122     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
01123     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01124   }
01125   //other checks are done internally in varoperatorvar
01126 
01127   // log message
01128   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing operation '%s' on seq variable '%s'"
01129                 " and variable '%s'", operation,
01130                 _fc_getVarSlot(seq_var1[0])->header.name,
01131                 _fc_getVarSlot(var2)->header.name);
01132 
01133   // Get info
01134   rc = fc_getSequenceFromSeqVariable(numStep, seq_var1, &seq);
01135   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01136     return rc;
01137 
01138   // Make space to save temp_vars
01139   temp_vars = malloc(numStep*sizeof(FC_Variable));
01140   if (!temp_vars) {
01141     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
01142     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
01143   }
01144 
01145   // Do calculation on each step of the seq variables
01146   for (i = 0; i < numStep; i++) {
01147     rc = fc_varOperatorVar(seq_var1[i], operation, var2, "junk_var",
01148                   &temp_vars[i]); 
01149     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS) { 
01150       for (j = 0; j < i-1; j++)
01151      fc_deleteVariable(temp_vars[j]);
01152       free(temp_vars);
01153       fc_printfErrorMessage("Operation failed on step %d", i);
01154       return rc;
01155     }
01156   }
01157 
01158   // stitch steps into the new seq var
01159   rc = fc_convertVariablesToSeqVariable(numStep, temp_vars, seq,
01160                          new_seq_var_name, new_seq_var);
01161   free(temp_vars);
01162   return rc;
01163 }
01164 
01165 /**
01166  * \ingroup  VariableMath
01167  * \brief Performs built-in binary operation on a seq variable and a normal var.
01168  *
01169  * \description 
01170  *
01171  *   Given a string that represents the desired binary operation, return a new
01172  *   seq variable with the result of that operation between a given
01173  *   seq variable and a normal var applied at each sequence step.
01174  *   For example, one can use this to scale a seqvar's values by their mean over
01175  *   the sequence (e.g., time).
01176  *
01177  *    Supported operations are:
01178  *     - <tt> "+"  =>  var1 + var2 </tt>
01179  *     - <tt> "-"  =>  var1 - var2 </tt>
01180  *     - <tt> "*"  =>  var1 * var2 </tt>
01181  *     - <tt> "/"  =>  var1 / var2 </tt>
01182  * 
01183  *    The two seq variable and the normal variable must have the same number of data
01184  *    points and the same number of components.
01185  *
01186  *    The seq new variable will be on the same mesh and sequence and will have the
01187  *    same association and mathtype as the seq variable. The operation is 
01188  *    performed per component and data point at each sequence step.
01189  *
01190  *    If both original variables have the data type FC_DT_INT, then the 
01191  *    operation will be an integer operation and the result
01192  *    will have data type FC_DT_INT. Otherwise, all variable values are
01193  *    promoted to double and the operation will be a double operation and
01194  *    the result will have data type FC_DT_DOUBLE.
01195  *    - 01/24/06  WSK Rewrote innards to mimimize data creation.
01196  *
01197  * \modifications 
01198  *    - 06/07/05  ACG  Created.
01199  *    - 01/24/06  WSK Rewrote innards to mimimize data creation.
01200  */
01201 FC_ReturnCode fc_varOperatorSeqVar(
01202   FC_Variable var1, /**< input var1 */
01203   char* operation,      /**< input - operation to be performed on variables */
01204   int numStep, /**< input - num step in input seq var */
01205   FC_Variable *seq_var2, /**< input seq var */
01206   char* new_seq_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */ 
01207   FC_Variable** new_seq_var  /**< output - the new seq variable */
01208 ) {   
01209   FC_ReturnCode rc;
01210   FC_Sequence seq;
01211   FC_Variable* temp_vars;
01212   int i, j;
01213 
01214   // default return
01215   if (new_seq_var)
01216     *new_seq_var = NULL;
01217 
01218   // check input
01219   if ((!fc_isVariableValid(var1)) ||
01220       (!fc_isSeqVariableValid(numStep, seq_var2)) ||
01221       (new_seq_var == NULL) || new_seq_var_name == NULL){
01222     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
01223     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01224   }
01225   //other checks are done internally in varoperatorvar
01226 
01227   // log message
01228   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing operation '%s' on variable '%s'"
01229                 " and seq variable '%s'", operation,
01230                 _fc_getVarSlot(var1)->header.name,
01231                 _fc_getVarSlot(seq_var2[0])->header.name);
01232 
01233   // Get info
01234   rc = fc_getSequenceFromSeqVariable(numStep, seq_var2, &seq);
01235   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01236     return rc;
01237 
01238   // Make space to save temp_vars
01239   temp_vars = malloc(numStep*sizeof(FC_Variable));
01240   if (!temp_vars) {
01241     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
01242     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
01243   }
01244 
01245   // Do calculation on each step of the seq variables
01246   for (i = 0; i < numStep; i++) {
01247     rc = fc_varOperatorVar(var1, operation, seq_var2[i],"junk_var",
01248                   &temp_vars[i]); 
01249     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS) { 
01250       for (j = 0; j < i-1; j++)
01251      fc_deleteVariable(temp_vars[j]);
01252       free(temp_vars);
01253       fc_printfErrorMessage("Operation failed on step %d", i);
01254       return rc;
01255     }
01256   }
01257 
01258   // stitch steps into the new seq var
01259   rc = fc_convertVariablesToSeqVariable(numStep, temp_vars, seq,
01260                          new_seq_var_name, new_seq_var);
01261   free(temp_vars);
01262   return rc;
01263 }
01264 
01265 /**
01266  * \ingroup  VariableMath
01267  * \brief Performs built-in binary operation on a seq variable and constant.
01268  *
01269  * \description 
01270  *
01271  *   Given a string that represents the desired binary operation, return a new
01272  *   seq variable with the result of that operation between a given
01273  *   seq variable and a constant applied at each sequence step.
01274  *
01275  *    Supported operations are:
01276  *     - <tt> "+"  =>  var + const </tt>
01277  *     - <tt> "-"  =>  var - const </tt>
01278  *     - <tt> "*"  =>  var * const </tt>
01279  *     - <tt> "/"  =>  var / const </tt>
01280  * 
01281  *    The seq variable and the constant must have the same number of components.
01282  *
01283  *    The seq new variable will be on the same mesh and sequence and will have
01284  *    the same association and mathtype as the seq variable. The operation is
01285  *    performed per component at each sequence step.
01286  *
01287  *    If both original variables have the data type FC_DT_INT, then the
01288  *    operation will be an integer operation and the result will have data type
01289  *    FC_DT_INT. Otherwise, all variable values are promoted to double and the
01290  *    operation will be a double operation and the result will have data type
01291  *    FC_DT_DOUBLE.
01292  *
01293  * \modifications 
01294  *    - 11/20/2006 WSD Created.
01295  */
01296 FC_ReturnCode fc_seqVarOperatorConst(
01297   int numStep, /**< input - num step in input seq var */
01298   FC_Variable *seq_var1, /**< input seq var1 */
01299   char* operation,       /**< input - operation to be performed on variables */
01300   int constNumComp,      /**< input - number of components in constVector */
01301   void* constVector,     /**< input - constant vector */
01302   FC_DataType constType, /**< input - data type of constVector */
01303   char* new_seq_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */ 
01304   FC_Variable** new_seq_var  /**< output - the new seq variable */
01305 ) {   
01306   FC_ReturnCode rc;
01307   FC_Sequence seq;
01308   FC_Variable* temp_vars;
01309   int i, j;
01310 
01311   // default return
01312   if (new_seq_var)
01313     *new_seq_var = NULL;
01314 
01315   // check input
01316   if ((!fc_isSeqVariableValid(numStep, seq_var1)) || !operation ||
01317       constNumComp < 1 || !constVector || !fc_isDataTypeValid(constType) ||
01318       constType == FC_DT_UNKNOWN ||
01319       (new_seq_var == NULL) || new_seq_var_name == NULL) {
01320     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
01321     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01322   }
01323   //other checks are done internally in varoperatorvar
01324 
01325   // log message
01326   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing operation '%s' on seq variable '%s'",
01327                       operation, 
01328                 _fc_getVarSlot(seq_var1[0])->header.name);
01329 
01330   // Get info
01331   rc = fc_getSequenceFromSeqVariable(numStep, seq_var1, &seq);
01332   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01333     return rc;
01334 
01335   // Make space to save temp_vars
01336   temp_vars = malloc(numStep*sizeof(FC_Variable));
01337   if (!temp_vars) {
01338     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
01339     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
01340   }
01341 
01342   // Do calculation on each step of the seq variables
01343   for (i = 0; i < numStep; i++) {
01344     rc = fc_varOperatorConst(seq_var1[i], operation, constNumComp, 
01345                              constVector, constType,
01346                              "junk_var", &temp_vars[i]); 
01347     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS) { 
01348       for (j = 0; j < i-1; j++)
01349      fc_deleteVariable(temp_vars[j]);
01350       free(temp_vars);
01351       fc_printfErrorMessage("Operation failed on step %d", i);
01352       return rc;
01353     }
01354   }
01355 
01356   // stitch steps into the new seq var
01357   rc = fc_convertVariablesToSeqVariable(numStep, temp_vars, seq,
01358                          new_seq_var_name, new_seq_var);
01359   free(temp_vars);
01360   return rc;
01361 }
01362 
01363 /**
01364  * \ingroup  VariableMath
01365  * \brief Performs built-in binary operation on a seq variable and constant.
01366  *
01367  * \description 
01368  *
01369  *   Given a string that represents the desired binary operation, return a new
01370  *   seq variable with the result of that operation between a given
01371  *   seq variable and a constant applied at each sequence step.
01372  *
01373  *    Supported operations are:
01374  *     - <tt> "+"  =>  const + var </tt>
01375  *     - <tt> "-"  =>  const - var </tt>
01376  *     - <tt> "*"  =>  const * var </tt>
01377  *     - <tt> "/"  =>  const / var </tt>
01378  * 
01379  *    The seq variable and the constant must have the same number of components.
01380  *
01381  *    The seq new variable will be on the same mesh and sequence and will have
01382  *    the same association and mathtype as the seq variable. The operation is
01383  *    performed per component at each sequence step.
01384  *
01385  *    If both original variables have the data type FC_DT_INT, then the
01386  *    operation will be an integer operation and the result will have data type
01387  *    FC_DT_INT. Otherwise, all variable values are promoted to double and the
01388  *    operation will be a double operation and the result will have data type
01389  *    FC_DT_DOUBLE.
01390  *
01391  * \modifications 
01392  *    - 11/20/2006 WSD Created.
01393  */
01394 FC_ReturnCode fc_constOperatorSeqVar(
01395   int constNumComp,      /**< input - number of components in constVector */
01396   void* constVector,     /**< input - constant vector */
01397   FC_DataType constType, /**< input - data type of constVector */
01398   char* operation,       /**< input - operation to be performed on variables */
01399   int numStep, /**< input - num step in input seq var */
01400   FC_Variable *seq_var2, /**< input seq var1 */
01401   char* new_seq_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */ 
01402   FC_Variable** new_seq_var  /**< output - the new seq variable */
01403 ) {   
01404   FC_ReturnCode rc;
01405   FC_Sequence seq;
01406   FC_Variable* temp_vars;
01407   int i, j;
01408 
01409   // default return
01410   if (new_seq_var)
01411     *new_seq_var = NULL;
01412 
01413   // check input
01414   if ((!fc_isSeqVariableValid(numStep, seq_var2)) || !operation ||
01415       constNumComp < 1 || !constVector || !fc_isDataTypeValid(constType) ||
01416       constType == FC_DT_UNKNOWN ||
01417       (new_seq_var == NULL) || new_seq_var_name == NULL) {
01418     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
01419     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01420   }
01421   //other checks are done internally in varoperatorvar
01422 
01423   // log message
01424   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing operation '%s' on seq variable '%s'",
01425                       operation, 
01426                 _fc_getVarSlot(seq_var2[0])->header.name);
01427 
01428   // Get info
01429   rc = fc_getSequenceFromSeqVariable(numStep, seq_var2, &seq);
01430   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01431     return rc;
01432 
01433   // Make space to save temp_vars
01434   temp_vars = malloc(numStep*sizeof(FC_Variable));
01435   if (!temp_vars) {
01436     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
01437     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
01438   }
01439 
01440   // Do calculation on each step of the seq variables
01441   for (i = 0; i < numStep; i++) {
01442     rc = fc_constOperatorVar(constNumComp, constVector, constType, operation, 
01443                              seq_var2[i], "junk_var", &temp_vars[i]); 
01444     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS) { 
01445       for (j = 0; j < i-1; j++)
01446      fc_deleteVariable(temp_vars[j]);
01447       free(temp_vars);
01448       fc_printfErrorMessage("Operation failed on step %d", i);
01449       return rc;
01450     }
01451   }
01452 
01453   // stitch steps into the new seq var
01454   rc = fc_convertVariablesToSeqVariable(numStep, temp_vars, seq,
01455                                         new_seq_var_name, new_seq_var);
01456   free(temp_vars);
01457   return rc;
01458 }
01459 
01460 //@}
01461 
01462 /** \name User supplied functions on variables. */
01463 //-------------------------------
01464 //@{
01465 
01466 /**
01467  * \ingroup  VariableMath
01468  * \brief Performs unary function on a variable.
01469  *
01470  * \description  
01471  *
01472  *    Given a unary function that takes a double and returns a double, this
01473  *    function creates a new variable whose values are the results of the
01474  *    function applied to the original variable's values.
01475  *
01476  *    The new variable will be on the same mesh as the original and will have
01477  *    the same association and math type as the original. The function is
01478  *    performed on each component of each data point. The new variable will
01479  *    always have data type FC_DT_DOUBLE. This function returns with an error
01480  *    if the data is FC_DT_CHAR.
01481  *
01482  * \modifications 
01483  *    - 02/26/04  R.McCoy  Created.
01484  */  
01485 FC_ReturnCode fc_varUnaryFunction(
01486   FC_Variable var,     /**< input - variable  */ 
01487   double (*unaryFunction)(double),
01488                         /**< input - function that operates on a double
01489                 and returns a double */     
01490   char* new_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */ 
01491   FC_Variable* new_var  /**< output - the new variable */
01492 ){
01493   FC_ReturnCode rc;
01494   int i;
01495   int numData;
01496   int numComp;
01497   int numTotalValues;
01498   FC_AssociationType assoc;
01499   FC_DataType datatype;
01500   FC_MathType mathtype;
01501   void *data;
01502   double *dblResultPtr;
01503 
01504   // set default return value
01505   if (new_var)
01506     *new_var = FC_NULL_VARIABLE;
01507 
01508   // check input
01509   if (!(fc_isVariableValid(var)) || !new_var_name || !new_var) {
01510     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
01511     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01512   }
01513   if (!unaryFunction) {
01514     fc_printfErrorMessage("Function was not provided");
01515     return FC_ERROR;
01516   }
01517   
01518   // log message
01519   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing unary user operation on variable '%s'",
01520             _fc_getVarSlot(var)->header.name);
01521 
01522   // get variable info
01523   rc = fc_getVariableInfo(var, &numData, &numComp, &assoc, &mathtype, 
01524                  &datatype);
01525   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01526     return rc;
01527 
01528   // check the datatype that can be handled here
01529   if (datatype != FC_DT_INT && datatype != FC_DT_FLOAT && 
01530       datatype != FC_DT_DOUBLE) {
01531     fc_printfErrorMessage("the datatype = %s type cannot be handled",
01532                  fc_getDataTypeText(datatype) );
01533     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01534   }  
01535 
01536   numTotalValues = numData * numComp;
01537 
01538   // get data
01539   rc = fc_getVariableDataPtr(var, &data);
01540   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01541     return rc; 
01542 
01543   // calc values
01544   dblResultPtr = malloc(sizeof(double)*numTotalValues);
01545   if (dblResultPtr == NULL) {
01546     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
01547     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;   
01548   }
01549   if (datatype == FC_DT_INT) {
01550     int* cast_data = (int*)data;
01551     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01552       dblResultPtr[i] = (*unaryFunction)(cast_data[i]);
01553   }
01554   else if (datatype == FC_DT_FLOAT) {
01555     float* cast_data = (float*)data;
01556     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01557       dblResultPtr[i] = (*unaryFunction)(cast_data[i]);
01558   }
01559   if (datatype == FC_DT_DOUBLE) {
01560     double* cast_data = (double*)data;
01561     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01562       dblResultPtr[i] = (*unaryFunction)(cast_data[i]);
01563   }
01564 
01565   // create the new variable
01566   if (fc_isVariableGlobal(var)) {
01567     FC_Dataset dataset;
01568     rc = fc_getDatasetFromVariable(var, &dataset);
01569     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01570       return rc;
01571     rc = fc_createGlobalVariable(dataset, new_var_name, new_var);
01572     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01573       return rc; 
01574   }
01575   else {
01576     FC_Mesh mesh;
01577     rc = fc_getMeshFromVariable(var, &mesh);
01578     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01579       return rc;
01580     rc = fc_createVariable(mesh, new_var_name, new_var);
01581     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01582       return rc; 
01583   }
01584   rc = fc_setVariableDataPtr(*new_var, numData, numComp, assoc, mathtype, 
01585                     FC_DT_DOUBLE, dblResultPtr);
01586   return rc;    
01587 }
01588 
01589 /**
01590  * \ingroup  VariableMath
01591  * \brief Performs binary function on two variables.
01592  *
01593  * \description
01594  *
01595  *    Given a binary function that takes two doubles and returns a double, this
01596  *    function creates a new variable whose values are the results of the
01597  *    function applied to the original variables' values.
01598  *
01599  *    The two variables must have the same number of data points and the same
01600  *    number of components.
01601  *
01602  *    The new variable will be on the same mesh and will have the same
01603  *    association and math type as the first variable. The function is applied
01604  *    per component and data point. The new variable will always have data type
01605  *    FC_DT_DOUBLE. This function returns with an error if the data is
01606  *    FC_DT_CHAR.
01607  *
01608  * \modifications 
01609  *    - 02/26/04  R.McCoy  Created.
01610  */  
01611 FC_ReturnCode fc_varBinaryFunctionVarVar(
01612   FC_Variable var1,     /**< input - variable 1  */
01613   FC_Variable var2,     /**< input - variable 2  */
01614   double (*binaryFunction)(double ddata1, double ddata2),
01615                         /**< input - function that operates on two doubles
01616                   and returns a double */
01617   char* new_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */
01618   FC_Variable* new_var  /**< output - the new variable */
01619 ){
01620   FC_ReturnCode rc;
01621   int i;
01622   int numData1, numData2, numComp1, numComp2, numTotalValues;
01623   FC_AssociationType assoc1, assoc2;
01624   FC_DataType datatype1, datatype2;
01625   FC_MathType mathtype1, mathtype2; 
01626   void *data1, *data2; 
01627   double *dblResultPtr;
01628 
01629   // set default return value
01630   if (new_var)
01631     *new_var = FC_NULL_VARIABLE;
01632 
01633   // check input
01634   if (!(fc_isVariableValid(var1)) || !(fc_isVariableValid(var2)) ||
01635       !new_var_name || !new_var) {
01636     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));   
01637     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01638   }
01639   if (!binaryFunction) {
01640     fc_printfErrorMessage("Function was not provided");      
01641     return FC_ERROR;
01642   }
01643 
01644   // log message
01645   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing binary user operation on var1 = '%s' and "
01646            "var2 = '%s'" , _fc_getVarSlot(var1)->header.name,
01647            _fc_getVarSlot(var2)->header.name  );  
01648 
01649   // get variable infos
01650   rc = fc_getVariableInfo(var1, &numData1, &numComp1, &assoc1, 
01651                             &mathtype1, &datatype1);
01652   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01653     return rc;
01654   rc = fc_getVariableInfo(var2, &numData2, &numComp2, &assoc2, 
01655                             &mathtype2, &datatype2);
01656   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01657     return rc;
01658 
01659   // check that variables are similar enough
01660   if (numData1 != numData2 || numComp1 != numComp2) {
01661     fc_printfErrorMessage("Variables are not similar enough.");
01662     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01663   }
01664 
01665   // check the data types that can be handled here
01666   if (datatype1 != FC_DT_INT && datatype1 != FC_DT_FLOAT && 
01667       datatype1 != FC_DT_DOUBLE) {
01668     fc_printfErrorMessage("datatype for variable 1 '%s' cannot be handled",
01669                  fc_getDataTypeText(datatype1));
01670     return FC_ERROR;
01671   } 
01672   if (datatype2 != FC_DT_INT && datatype2 != FC_DT_FLOAT && 
01673       datatype2 != FC_DT_DOUBLE) {
01674     fc_printfErrorMessage("datatype2 for variable 2 '%s' cannot be handled",
01675                  fc_getDataTypeText(datatype2));
01676     return FC_ERROR;
01677   }
01678 
01679   numTotalValues = numData1 * numComp1;
01680 
01681   // get data
01682   rc = fc_getVariableDataPtr(var1, &data1);
01683   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01684     return rc;
01685   rc = fc_getVariableDataPtr(var2, &data2);
01686   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01687     return rc;
01688 
01689   // calc values -- 9 combinations of type
01690   dblResultPtr = malloc(sizeof(double)*numTotalValues);
01691   if (dblResultPtr == NULL) {
01692     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
01693     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;   
01694   }
01695   if (datatype1 == FC_DT_INT && datatype2 == FC_DT_INT) {
01696     int* cast_data1 = (int*)data1;
01697     int* cast_data2 = (int*)data2;
01698     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01699       dblResultPtr[i] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data1[i], cast_data2[i]);
01700   }
01701   else if (datatype1 == FC_DT_INT && datatype2 == FC_DT_FLOAT) {
01702     int* cast_data1 = (int*)data1;
01703     float* cast_data2 = (float*)data2;
01704     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01705       dblResultPtr[i] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data1[i], cast_data2[i]);
01706   }
01707   else if (datatype1 == FC_DT_INT && datatype2 == FC_DT_DOUBLE) {
01708     int* cast_data1 = (int*)data1;
01709     double* cast_data2 = (double*)data2;
01710     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01711       dblResultPtr[i] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data1[i], cast_data2[i]);
01712   }
01713   else if (datatype1 == FC_DT_FLOAT && datatype2 == FC_DT_INT) {
01714     float* cast_data1 = (float*)data1;
01715     int* cast_data2 = (int*)data2;
01716     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01717       dblResultPtr[i] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data1[i], cast_data2[i]);
01718   }
01719   else if (datatype1 == FC_DT_FLOAT && datatype2 == FC_DT_FLOAT) {
01720     float* cast_data1 = (float*)data1;
01721     float* cast_data2 = (float*)data2;
01722     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01723       dblResultPtr[i] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data1[i], cast_data2[i]);
01724   }
01725   else if (datatype1 == FC_DT_FLOAT && datatype2 == FC_DT_DOUBLE) {
01726     float* cast_data1 = (float*)data1;
01727     double* cast_data2 = (double*)data2;
01728     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01729       dblResultPtr[i] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data1[i], cast_data2[i]);
01730   }
01731   else if (datatype1 == FC_DT_DOUBLE && datatype2 == FC_DT_INT) {
01732     double* cast_data1 = (double*)data1;
01733     int* cast_data2 = (int*)data2;
01734     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01735       dblResultPtr[i] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data1[i], cast_data2[i]);
01736   }
01737   else if (datatype1 == FC_DT_DOUBLE && datatype2 == FC_DT_FLOAT) {
01738     double* cast_data1 = (double*)data1;
01739     float* cast_data2 = (float*)data2;
01740     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01741       dblResultPtr[i] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data1[i], cast_data2[i]);
01742   }
01743   else if (datatype1 == FC_DT_DOUBLE && datatype2 == FC_DT_DOUBLE) {
01744     double* cast_data1 = (double*)data1;
01745     double* cast_data2 = (double*)data2;
01746     for (i = 0; i < numTotalValues; i++)
01747       dblResultPtr[i] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data1[i], cast_data2[i]);
01748   }
01749   else {
01750     fc_printfErrorMessage("Should never reach here, error in code!\n");
01751     return FC_ERROR;
01752   }
01753 
01754   // create the new variable -- put on same mesh as first variable
01755   if (fc_isVariableGlobal(var1)) {
01756     FC_Dataset dataset;
01757     rc = fc_getDatasetFromVariable(var1, &dataset);
01758     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01759       return rc;
01760     rc = fc_createGlobalVariable(dataset, new_var_name, new_var);
01761     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01762       return rc; 
01763   }
01764   else {
01765     FC_Mesh mesh;
01766     rc = fc_getMeshFromVariable(var1, &mesh);
01767     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01768       return rc;
01769     rc = fc_createVariable(mesh, new_var_name, new_var);
01770     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01771       return rc; 
01772   }
01773   rc = fc_setVariableDataPtr(*new_var, numData1, numComp1, assoc1, mathtype1, 
01774                     FC_DT_DOUBLE, dblResultPtr);
01775   return rc;
01776 }
01777 
01778 /**
01779  * \ingroup  VariableMath
01780  * \brief Performs binary function on a variable and a constant.
01781  *
01782  * \description
01783  *
01784  *    Given a binary function that takes two doubles and returns a double, this
01785  *    function creates a new variable whose values are the results of the
01786  *    function applied with the constant to each data point of the variable.
01787  *    Use fc_varBinaryFunctionConstVar() to apply the function in reverse
01788  *    order.
01789  *
01790  *    The variable and the constant must have the same number of components.
01791  *
01792  *    The new variable will be on the same mesh and will have the same
01793  *    association and math type as the variable. The function is applied
01794  *    per component and data point. The new variable will always have data type
01795  *    FC_DT_DOUBLE. This function returns with an error if the data is
01796  *    FC_DT_CHAR.
01797  *
01798  * \modifications 
01799  *    - 11/09/04 WSK, created.
01800  */  
01801 FC_ReturnCode fc_varBinaryFunctionVarConst(
01802   FC_Variable var,      /**< input - variable */
01803   int constNumComp,     /**< input - number of components in constant */
01804   double* constValues,  /**< input - the values of the constant */
01805   double (*binaryFunction)(double, double),
01806                         /**< input - function that operates on two doubles
01807                   and returns a double */
01808   char* new_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */
01809   FC_Variable* new_var  /**< output - the new variable */
01810 ){
01811   FC_ReturnCode rc;
01812   int i, j;
01813   int numData, numComp;
01814   FC_AssociationType assoc;
01815   FC_DataType datatype;
01816   FC_MathType mathtype; 
01817   void *data; 
01818   double *dblResultPtr;
01819 
01820   // set default return value
01821   if (new_var)
01822     *new_var = FC_NULL_VARIABLE;
01823 
01824   // check input
01825   if (!(fc_isVariableValid(var)) || constNumComp < 1 || !constValues ||
01826       !new_var_name || !new_var) {
01827     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));   
01828     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01829   }
01830   if (!binaryFunction) {
01831     fc_printfErrorMessage("Function was not provided");      
01832     return FC_ERROR;
01833   }
01834 
01835   // log message
01836   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing binary user operation on var = '%s' and "
01837            "a constant" , _fc_getVarSlot(var)->header.name);  
01838 
01839   // get variable info
01840   rc = fc_getVariableInfo(var, &numData, &numComp, &assoc, 
01841                  &mathtype, &datatype);
01842   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01843     return rc;
01844 
01845   // check that variables and const are similar enough
01846   if (numComp != constNumComp) {
01847     fc_printfErrorMessage("Variables and const do not have the same numComp");
01848     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01849   }
01850 
01851   // check that the datatype can be handled here
01852   if (datatype != FC_DT_INT && datatype != FC_DT_FLOAT && 
01853       datatype != FC_DT_DOUBLE) {
01854     fc_printfErrorMessage("datatype '%s' cannot be handled",
01855                  fc_getDataTypeText(datatype));
01856     return FC_ERROR;
01857   }
01858 
01859   // get data
01860   rc = fc_getVariableDataPtr(var, &data);
01861   if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01862     return rc;
01863 
01864   // calc values
01865   dblResultPtr = malloc(sizeof(double)*numData*numComp);
01866   if (dblResultPtr == NULL) {
01867     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
01868     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;   
01869   }
01870   if (datatype == FC_DT_INT) {
01871     int* cast_data = (int*)data;
01872     for (i = 0; i < numData; i++)
01873       for (j = 0; j < numComp; j++)
01874      dblResultPtr[i*numComp+j] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data[i*numComp+j], 
01875                                   constValues[j]);
01876   }
01877   else if (datatype == FC_DT_FLOAT) {
01878     float* cast_data = (float*)data;
01879     for (i = 0; i < numData; i++)
01880       for (j = 0; j < numComp; j++)
01881      dblResultPtr[i*numComp+j] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data[i*numComp+j], 
01882                                   constValues[j]);
01883   }
01884   else if (datatype == FC_DT_DOUBLE) {
01885     double* cast_data = (double*)data;
01886     for (i = 0; i < numData; i++)
01887       for (j = 0; j < numComp; j++)
01888      dblResultPtr[i*numComp+j] = (*binaryFunction)(cast_data[i*numComp+j], 
01889                                   constValues[j]);
01890   }
01891   else {
01892     fc_printfErrorMessage("Should never reach here, error in code!\n");
01893     return FC_ERROR;
01894   }
01895 
01896   // create the new variable
01897   if (fc_isVariableGlobal(var)) {
01898     FC_Dataset dataset;
01899     rc = fc_getDatasetFromVariable(var, &dataset);
01900     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01901       return rc;
01902     rc = fc_createGlobalVariable(dataset, new_var_name, new_var);
01903     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01904       return rc; 
01905   }
01906   else {
01907     FC_Mesh mesh;
01908     rc = fc_getMeshFromVariable(var, &mesh);
01909     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01910       return rc;
01911     rc = fc_createVariable(mesh, new_var_name, new_var);
01912     if (rc != FC_SUCCESS)
01913       return rc; 
01914   }
01915   rc = fc_setVariableDataPtr(*new_var, numData, numComp, assoc, mathtype, 
01916                     FC_DT_DOUBLE, dblResultPtr);
01917   return rc;
01918 }
01919 
01920 /**
01921  * \ingroup  VariableMath
01922  * \brief Performs binary function on a constant and a variable.
01923  *
01924  * \description
01925  *
01926  *    Given a binary function that takes two doubles and returns a double, this
01927  *    function creates a new variable whose values are the results of the
01928  *    function applied with the constant to each data point of the variable.
01929  *    Use fc_varBinaryFunctionConstVar() to apply the function in reverse
01930  *    order.
01931  *
01932  *    The variable and the constant must have the same number of components.
01933  *
01934  *    The new variable will be on the same mesh and will have the same
01935  *    association and math type as the variable. The function is applied
01936  *    per component and data point. The new variable will always have data type
01937  *    FC_DT_DOUBLE. This function returns with an error if the data is
01938  *    FC_DT_CHAR.
01939  *
01940  * \modifications 
01941  *    - 11/09/04 WSK, created.
01942  */
01943 FC_ReturnCode fc_varBinaryFunctionConstVar(
01944   int constNumComp,     /**< input - number of components in constant */
01945   double* constValues,  /**< input - the values of the constant */
01946   FC_Variable var,      /**< input - variable */
01947   double (*binaryFunction)(double, double),
01948                         /**< input - function that operates on two doubles
01949                   and returns a double */
01950   char* new_var_name,   /**< input - name for the new variable */
01951   FC_Variable* new_var  /**< output - the new variable */
01952 ){
01953   FC_ReturnCode rc;
01954   int i, j;
01955   int numData, numComp;
01956   FC_AssociationType assoc;
01957   FC_DataType datatype;
01958   FC_MathType mathtype; 
01959   void *data; 
01960   double *dblResultPtr;
01961 
01962   // set default return value
01963   if (new_var)
01964     *new_var = FC_NULL_VARIABLE;
01965 
01966   // check input
01967   if (!(fc_isVariableValid(var)) || constNumComp < 1 || !constValues ||
01968       !new_var_name || !new_var) {
01969     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));   
01970     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
01971   }
01972   if (!binaryFunction) {
01973     fc_printfErrorMessage("Function was not provided");      
01974     return FC_ERROR;
01975   }
01976 
01977   // log message
01978   fc_printfLogMessage("Performing binary user operation on var = '%s' and "
01979            "a constant" , _fc_getVarSlot(var)->header.name);  
01980 
01981   // get variable info
